Bob Hart, a managing associate at Foster Partners, a New York firm that specializes in career counseling, had this advice for job hunters. NETWORKING: The most important thing to do in an overcrowded job market is to build contacts through alumni groups, fraternal organizations, friends and former colleagues. OTHER APPROACHES: Respond to newspaper advertisements, be willing to relocate, follow up on leads from search firms and organize a letter campaign to potential employers. DURING AN INTERVIEW: Never criticize your former company or its management. Do not show dissatisfaction with the interview itself. Make it as productive as possible and evaluate it afterward. Do not bring up salary. It will come up in subsequent interviews when appropriate. Do not plead for a position. Be a good listener. Do not try to take control of the interview; it is a give-and-take process. Be relaxed and willing to discuss hobbies and such, but do not get so relaxed that you, say, show pictures of your children. Do not discount what executive-search companies or human-resource departments may be able to do for you. (Source: Foster Partners)

title: Save Our Stations
description: The Federal Communications Commission recently announced that it will greatly increase the number of TV and radio stations an individual, company or religious group can own. In radio, the limit is to rise from 24 to 60 stations apiece; companies will be allowed to own as many as six stations in one city. In TV, companies will be permitted to own as many as 24 stations, up from 12. These steps are likely to lead to monopoly ownership in U.S. broadcasting and, eventually, to a steep decline in news and public affairs.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMC ENTERTAINMENT INC., Kansas City, Mo., said its American Multi-Cinema Inc. unit had completed the sale of five theaters to Carmike Cinemas Inc., Columbus, Ga. Terms were not disclosed. CSX CORP., Richmond, a transportation holding company; American Commercial Lines Inc., Jeffersonville, Ind., and Sequa Corp., completed sale of the assets of the Valley Line Company, Sequa's barge unit, to CSX.

title: Blazers Get Defensive Too Late
description: The Utah Jazz spent the late night talking about its defense and its new momentum, but it was Rick Adelman, the coach of the Portland Trail Blazers, who seemed to set a small brush fire tonight after Game 3 of the Western Conference final.

title: Research Files Thrown Away At Columbia
description: Federal auditors at Columbia University reported yesterday that important records accounting for more than $60 million in Federal research costs in 1986 have been destroyed, even though Columbia knew the government might need them to determine the extent to which inappropriate expenses had been charged to taxpayers.

title: On the Trail
description: PEROT GAVE $850,000 LAST MONTH TO BALLOTS COMMITTEE

title: Town & Country Editor Dismissed After 6 Months on Job
description: Ron Javers, editor in chief of Town & Country, was dismissed on Thursday, six months after he had been appointed by D. Claeys Bahrenburg, president of Hearst Magazines, as "the ideal editor to lead Town & Country into the 21st century," Hearst employees said.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: House Race; After 115 Years, a Black Will Represent Alabama
description: The one thing that is certain about the crowded field seeking to represent Alabama's newly apportioned Seventh Congressional District is that from its ranks will come the state's first black member of Congress in 115 years.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Janice Weber Pianist Steinway Hall

title: Women March Home To Recognition at Last
description: WHEN the New Haven Memorial Day Parade steps off today, a woman will be at the head of the march for the first time in its history. Dr. Doris Troth Lippman of Westport, a professor of nursing at Fairfield University and a Vietnam veteran, will lead the parade down Chapel Street at 2 this afternoon.

title: Recalling a 'Skirmish on Poverty'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bringing the Artistic Life To an Old Red-Brick School
description: A SO-CALLED fleeting idea that happened to linger, a "funny little dream" that became a reality -- this is the way Lee Pope, owner of the Schoolhouse on Owens Road here, describes her venture.

title: Making It in the Majors
description: Even on a day like today, when the breeze that rustles the grass on an Indiana baseball diamond has kept tempers cool and spirits up, Penny Marshall is gloomy. The director of the back-to-back hits "Big" and "Awakenings" had thought it would be refreshing to spend the summer in the Midwest's affable sunshine directing "A League of Their Own," about two baseball-playing sisters.

title: Read This!
description: THE corner newsstand, as visually dense and jumbled as MTV or a news reporter's desk, is perhaps the second mirror we look into each morning. As one bends over to pick up the morning paper, the eye roves over the serious headlines of the day, as well as snack food for the brain: the eclectic assortment of magazines that blasts your sensibilities and yanks at your self-esteem.

title: Abigail Goodnough, J. F. Hassell 4th
description: August wedding plans for Abigail Susan Goodnough and John Fleming Hassell 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hassell 3d of Charleston, S.C., have been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. C. Peter Goodnough of Elmira, N.Y.

title: Mediation Smooths the Way Toward Divorce
description: AT the Divorce Mediation Center in West Hartford a couple can divide the assets of a marriage and develop a settlement agreement and petition that can be brought to court in an uncontested divorce.

title: Hamburg Airport
description: To the Editor: Friends of mine in New York (where I lived for 27 years until October 1990) sent me your informative feature about my new domicile, "What's Doing in Hamburg (Feb. 16), which is excellent on all our good points. It leaves out the "warts," but these may become apparent only to permanent residents.

title: Making a Difference; The 'Real' Murphy Brown
description: "From every source available to us, the same story emerges," Robert S. Alley and Irby B. Brown wrote in their 1990 book, "Murphy Brown: Anatomy of a Sitcom" (Delta Books). "Murphy Brown is Diane English."

title: An Open Letter To Fay Vincent
description: Dear Mr. Vincent:

title: Mary McGowan, Gregory S. Heins
description: Mary Ellen McGowan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence A. McGowan Jr. of Philadelphia, was married there yesterday to Gregory Saylor Heins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Heins 2d of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. William Graham performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Old St. Joseph's Church.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League HOUSTON ASTROS -- Optioned Luis Gonzalez, outfielder, to Tucson of the Pacific Coast League. Activated Rob Murphy, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list.

title: A Fair Shake Is Sought For Left-Handed People
description: WHILE growing up, John Diana of Port Jefferson found himself left out of a right-handed world. Remembering his childhood, he recalled often being at a disadvantage because of his left-handedness.

title: Airport's Ill Winds
description: In the wreckage of an ambitious but ill-fated plan to rebuild Kennedy International Airport lies at least $100 million in waste, a handful of half-finished and now mostly useless construction projects and plenty of attempts to lay blame at someone else's door.

title: Hertz to Join Avis in Offering Methanol Cars
description: Hertz plans to join Avis in bringing to car rental counters in Sacramento, Calif., the brave new world of low-pollution cars that run on something besides gasoline.

title: Guns Are Result, Not Cause, of Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Prelude To Sounds And Sights Of Nature
description: The spring rain had been falling all morning. But among the 10 New York City families gathered for the weekend, few spirits were dampened.

title: P.S. 30's Helping Hands: College Mentors
description: WHEN Mathilda Cuomo, a strong advocate of public education, suggested that every sixth grader in the state's schools be assigned a mentor, the administrators at Public School 30 in Yonkers thought the idea had merit and got in touch with their neighbor, Sarah Lawrence College, where there are no specific majors.

title: MAY 17-23: J. F. K. Autopsy; After 29 Years of Silence, The Pathologists Speak Up
description: In 1963, the two U.S. Navy pathologists who performed the autopsy on President John F. Kennedy concluded that he was hit by only two bullets, fired from above and behind, and killed when one exploded in his skull.

title: Dealer Sues U.S. Over Seized Tyrannosaur Bones
description: In the latest twist in a tortuous legal battle for custody of a 65-million-year-old dinosaur skeleton, a South Dakota fossil dealer has filed a lawsuit against the Federal Government that lawyers believe might eventually reach the Supreme Court.

title: Sicily Bomb Kills Anti-Mafia Fighter and 5 Others
description: One of Italy's senior anti-Mafia investigators, who had been expected to head a new agency to combat organized crime, was slain in Sicily today when a car bomb blasted his bullet-proof sedan. At least five other people also died in the attack, the police and news reports said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 10 about the film "The Waterdance" misidentified the producers. They are Gayle Anne Hurd and Marie Cantin.

title: Sarah Paddock, Ed Wright
description: Sarah Elizabeth Paddock, a daughter of Maj. Geoffrey J. Paddock of Kent, England, and Helen Paddock of Huish Champflower, England, was married yesterday to Charles Edward Wright Jr., the son of June E. Wright of Denver and the late Mr. Wright. Vicar Jerry Bird performed the Anglican ceremony at St. Peter's Church in Huish Champflower.

title: Riverside Controversy Reveals Conflicts of Racial Transition
description: To the Editor:

title:
RECORDINGS VIEW;
Wynonna Judd Stands Alone
description: In 1984, two years before the advent of new traditionalism, the Judds anticipated country music's return to honky-tonk Americana with songs like "Mama, He's Crazy" and "Why Not Me." Their music thumped and sparkled with clean, rhythmic band arrangements and brimmed with Appalachian character.

title: On Global Warming; Why So Chilly?
description: The Bush Administration has drawn sharp criticism for weakening the global warming treaty that will be signed at the United Nations environmental summit in Brazil next month. The treaty will set no firm targets and timetables for reducing the emission of greenhouse gases that could alter world climate. It will simply require countries to adopt greenhouse-reduction programs.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Jersey; Perot, Little Known, Is a Wild Card in New Jersey
description: With Bill Clinton and George Bush apparently assured of their parties' nominations, the only political wild card in New Jersey is Ross Perot, the independent candidate from Texas.

title: Teases That Backfire
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dinner Trade
description: At the New York Stock Exchange; May 16, 7 P.M.

title: The Score Is Advantage, Foie Gras
description: FAR more than a mere tennis tournament, the French Open provides a vivid microcosm of Paris, and a tourist eager to understand this city could do a lot worse than spend a day or two strolling the grounds of Roland Garros Stadium. For two weeks at the end of May and the beginning of June, this multilayered event manages to compress into a 20-acre enclave at the edge of the Bois de Boulogne all the essential Parisian hallmarks -- high fashion, haute cuisine, high-handed evocations of the nation's past glory, ham-handed insistence on linguistic correctness, copious wine, rampant commercialism and pure artistry, on court and off.

title: Leonard Horowitz, 44, Heart-Rhythm Expert
description: Leonard N. Horowitz, a cardiologist who was an expert in diagnosing and treating abnormal heart rhythms, died Thursday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 44 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: 100 Years of Doctoring
description: THE LIFE AND DEATH OF MY MOTHER By Allen Wheelis. 128 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company.

title: Kristen Minor and Nathan Corser
description: Kristen Minor, a daughter of Susan Miranda and Michael Minor, both of Los Alamos, N.M., was married yesterday in San Juan Pueblo, N.M., to Nathan Clark Corser, a son of Elizabeth B. and Dallas L. Corser of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Dale Arnink performed the Unitarian ceremony at Swan Lake Ranch.

title: Tie-Dye With Gravy Strains
description: Ben & Jerry's is repackaging the 1960's. In the fall, the Vermont ice cream company plans to introduce a flavor called Wavy Gravy, after the master of ceremonies at the Woodstock Festival in 1969. The ice cream will be sold in containers with a tie-dye design.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE HEARSTSFather and Son.By William Randolph Hearst Jr.with Jack Casserly.Roberts Rinehart, $29.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GARDEN STATEBy Rick Moody.Pushcart Press, $18.50.

title:
DINING OUT;
The French Touch in Briarcliff Manor
description: MAXIME RIBERA and Bernard Le Bris have long been recognized as two of Westchester's enduring culinary artists and among the few chefs who have successfully placed French haute cuisine on the county map. Ever sensitive to culinary trends, they have now done another good thing in bringing workaday, but nonetheless delicious, French cooking to the area.

title: Lisa Jayne, Matthew Sippel
description: Lisa LaForge Jayne, a daughter of Mrs. David W. Jayne 3d of Pelham, N.Y., and the late Mr. Jayne, was married yesterday in New York to Matthew John Sippel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert C. Sippel of Kenmore, N.Y. The Rev. Timothy S. Healy performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Church.

title: For Troubled Co-ops, the Workout Rx
description: THREE years after sponsor defaults began undermining the financial health of hundreds of New York City's converted co-ops and condominiums, the pace of new defaults has slowed considerably and many troubled buildings are working their way back to stability.
